		     iv)    Liquidity Risk
                                                                                                                                                         C.   Hedge Accounting
              Liquidity risk arises from the Group’s inability to meet its cash flow commitments on the due date. The Group maintains
                                                                                                                                                              The Group’s business objective includes safe-guarding its earnings against adverse price movements of crude oil and other
              sufficient stock of cash, marketable securities and committed credit facilities. The Group accesses global and local financial                  feedstock, refined products, precious metals, freight costs as well as foreign exchange and interest rates. The Group has
              markets to meet its liquidity requirements. It uses a range of products and a mix of currencies to ensure efficient funding                     adopted a structured risk management policy to hedge all these risks within an acceptable risk limit and an approved hedge
              from across well-diversified markets and investor pools. Treasury monitors rolling forecasts of the Group’s cash flow                           accounting framework which allows for Fair Value and Cash Flow hedges. Hedging instruments include exchange traded
                                                                                                                                                              futures and options, over-the-counter swaps, forwards and options as well as non-derivative instruments to achieve this
              position and ensures that the Group is able to meet its financial obligation at all times including contingencies.
                                                                                                                                                              objective.
              The Group’s liquidity is managed centrally with operating units forecasting their cash and liquidity requirements. Treasury                    There is an economic relationship between the hedged items and the hedging instruments. The Group has established a
              pools the cash surpluses from across the different operating units and then arranges to either fund the net deficit or invest                   hedge ratio of 1:1 for the hedging relationships. To test the hedge effectiveness, the Group uses the hypothetical derivative
              the net surplus in a range of short-dated, secure and liquid instruments including short-term bank deposits, money market                       method and Dollar offset method.
              funds, reverse repos and similar instruments. The portfolio of these investments is diversified to avoid concentration risk in                  The hedge ineffectiveness can arise from:
              any one instrument or counterparty.                                                                                                             - Differences in the timing of the cash flows.

35.    Capital Management                                                                                                                              Other Financial Liabilities                 3,097             -       3,097                -       2,425                -        2,425                -
       The Company adheres to a disciplined Capital Management framework in order to maintain a strong balance sheet. The main                       * Exclude Group company investments H 2,49,882 crore (Previous Year H 2,18,569 crore) measured at cost (Refer Note 2.1).
        objectives are as follows:
       a)    Maintain AAA rating domestically and investment grade rating internationally.
       b)    Manage foreign exchange, interest rates and commodity price risk, and minimise the impact of market volatility on earnings.
       c)    Diversify sources of financing and spread the maturity across tenure buckets in order to manage liquidity risk.
       d)    Leverage optimally in order to maximise shareholder returns.
